nodes.text: Firms (a contractual organization with a central residual claimant) emerge because they lower the costs of metering productivity and disciplining shirking in team production, making team production economically viable relative to market exchange
Team production is production using multiple inputs where the joint product is not the sum of separable individual outputs, so individual marginal products are difficult to observe from total output
An economic organization must meter input productivity and meter rewards to align incentives; poor metering reduces productivity while good metering increases productivity
Monitoring each team member's contribution is costly, so decentralized market mechanisms often fail to detect shirking and to assign rewards in proportion to marginal product in team settings

A contractual structure in which one party is common to all input contracts, holds the residual claim, can unilaterally revise individual contracts, and can sell that status constitutes the classical firm and reduces monitoring costs
Because individual shirking imposes costs on other team members and detection is costly, team members will choose more leisure and shirk more than under costless monitoring, lowering total output
Decentralized replacement by outsiders can discipline shirkers only imperfectly: outsiders must detect where shirking occurs and new members bear less than full marginal loss, limiting deterrence

Specializing a monitor who is made residual claimant aligns incentives to reduce shirking because the monitor internalizes gains from reduced shirking and can observe and direct inputs to estimate marginal productivity

Metering costs create a tradeoff: relying on markets increases information about marginal products but can be costlier for team production, whereas central monitoring reduces shirking-related losses despite managerial agency costs

Different organizational forms (profit-sharing partnerships, corporations, socialist enterprises, nonprofits, unions) arise as responses to the monitoring and residual-claim allocation problem under varying constraints and input characteristics

Inputs likely to be owned by the residual-claimant are durable assets with high resale value or long useful life because ownership demonstrates capacity to cover negative residuals and eases monitoring of user-induced depreciation

Profit sharing is more viable for small teams or professional/artistic work where self-monitoring and reciprocal monitoring reduce shirking costs, whereas dispersed residual claims in large teams raise monitor shirking risks

Corporations mitigate monitoring and delegated authority problems by concentrating decision authority in managers, enabling sale of shares for exit, and using salability and occasional concentrated votes to discipline managers

Firms function as specialized private markets that collect, collate, and sell information about heterogeneous inputs; this internal information advantage promotes intrafirm recombination of inputs and growth of firms

Implications and testable predictions include: relative incidence of profit sharing in small professional teams, existence of worker committees or external constraints in politically imposed employee-owned firms, ownership patterns of durable inputs, and greater shirking in mutual/nonprofit firms where future benefits are not capitalized into tradable claims
